description:
Candidatus Tisiphia is a bacterial endosymbiont species that resides within the body of the fly Melanophora roralis, also known as the black dung fly. This bacterial species is classified as a "Candidatus" taxa, which means it has not been fully cultured and characterized in a laboratory setting, but its existence and genomic information have been inferred through metagenomics and other molecular techniques.

The Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont is believed to be an obligate intracellular bacterium, meaning it can only survive and reproduce within the host cells of the Melanophora roralis fly. The exact nature of the relationship between the bacterium and its host is not fully understood, but it is thought to be a mutualistic symbiosis, where both organisms benefit from the association.

Genomic analyses of the Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont have revealed that it has a reduced genome size compared to free-living bacteria, which is a common characteristic of obligate intracellular symbionts. This reduction in genome size is likely due to the stable and nutrient-rich environment provided by the host, allowing the bacterium to lose genes that are no longer necessary for its survival.

The exact functions and contributions of the Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont to the host fly are still under investigation, but it is possible that it plays a role in nutrient provision, defense against pathogens, or other aspects of the fly's biology and ecology.
